Literature Review: The study of free surface flows, particularly those involving singularities such as drop/bubble breakup or coalescence and film/sheet rupture, presents a significant challenge in fluid dynamics. These phenomena are characterized by their multiscale nature, requiring the capture of dynamics over a wide range of length scales, often spanning five to six orders of magnitude. Sharp interface methods have emerged as a powerful tool for simulating and analyzing these complex flows, offering the resolution necessary to accurately model the intricate processes involved. This literature review explores the advancements in the field of interfacial flows with hydrodynamic singularities, focusing on the contributions of sharp interface algorithms. Drop breakup and coalescence are quintessential examples of free surface flows with singularities. In the case of drop breakup, the formation and eventual pinch-off of fluid threads necessitate simulations that can resolve the thinning process down to a thread radius of approximately 10 nm. Similarly, the coalescence of two drops requires the simulation of the thinning of the fluid film separating them until its thickness falls below 10 nm. Given that the initial drop radii can be on the order of 1 mm, simulations must accurately capture the physics as the thread radius or film thickness decreases from 10^-3 m to below 10^-8 m. Sharp interface methods have been instrumental in achieving this level of resolution. These multidimensional algorithms have enabled researchers to simulate free surface flows with a fidelity that was previously only attainable with simpler, one-dimensional evolution equations. The ability of sharp interface methods to accurately capture the dynamics of fluid threads and films at the nanoscale has opened new avenues for research in areas such as ink jet printing, microfluidics, and sprays. One of the key challenges in simulating free surface flows with singularities is the accurate representation of the interface between different phases. Sharp interface methods address this challenge by explicitly tracking the interface, allowing for the precise calculation of surface tension forces and the accurate resolution of the flow near the interface. This capability is crucial for modeling the breakup and coalescence of drops, as these processes are highly sensitive to the dynamics at the interface. Recent studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of sharp interface methods in simulating complex free surface flows. For example, the work of [Author 1 et al.] has shown that these methods can accurately capture the dynamics of drop breakup, including the formation of satellite drops and the thinning of fluid threads. Similarly, [Author 2 et al.] have used sharp interface methods to study the coalescence of drops, providing insights into the mechanisms that drive this process. In addition to their application in drop breakup and coalescence, sharp interface methods have also been used to study other types of free surface flows with singularities. For instance, [Author 3 et al.] have applied these methods to the study of jet breakup, a process that is relevant to applications such as ink jet printing and spray formation. Their work has demonstrated the ability of sharp interface methods to capture the complex dynamics of jet breakup, including the formation of droplets and the interaction of the jet with the surrounding air. The development of sharp interface methods has also been driven by advances in computational techniques and hardware. The increasing availability of high-performance computing resources has enabled researchers to perform simulations with unprecedented levels of resolution and accuracy. This has allowed for the detailed study of free surface flows with singularities, providing new insights into the underlying physics of these phenomena. Despite the significant progress that has been made, challenges remain in the simulation of free surface flows with singularities. One of the key challenges is the development of algorithms that can efficiently handle the multiscale nature of these flows. While sharp interface methods have proven to be effective, further research is needed to improve their efficiency and scalability. Additionally, the integration of sharp interface methods with other computational techniques, such as molecular dynamics simulations, could provide a more comprehensive understanding of the processes involved in drop breakup and coalescence. In conclusion, sharp interface methods have played a pivotal role in advancing our understanding of free surface flows with singularities. These methods have enabled researchers to accurately simulate complex phenomena such as drop breakup and coalescence, providing valuable insights into the underlying physics. As computational techniques and hardware continue to evolve, it is likely that sharp interface methods will remain at the forefront of research in this field, driving further advancements in our understanding of free surface flows.
